Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2019 MINDS (Mentoring for Innovative Design Solutions) Workshop organized by Alpha Eta Mu Beta, the National Biomedical Engineering Honors Society, will be held in parallel with the Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES) Annual Meeting on October 17-20, 2019 in Philadelphia, PA. This award will support student travel to the MINDS Workshop and BMES Annual Meeting. The MINDS Scholar Program provides students with the opportunity to collaborate and network with peers and mentors from across the country for a 5-month period, while building necessary engineering design skills. The students would also learn about design considerations that are not usually stressed in coursework projects: (1) market considerations for commercialization, (2) regulatory strategy, and (3) evaluating prospects for intellectual property protection.

Students will be selected through a competitive process, with junior undergraduates preferred. Students will then work with their teams and mentors to develop a design solution, and subject matter experts will provide support to the teams during this five-month design period. Teams will be encouraged to submit their designs to various design contests, investment opportunities, and grant programs. This program will develop a core group of engineers who will better understand the importance of considering human needs before attempting to design devices. Additionally, the collaborative and long-distance communication skills that students will develop in this project will better equip them to work in an environment that is increasingly dependent on communication between distant facilities and customers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Alpha Eta Mu Beta (AHMB), the international biomedical engineering honor society, recognizes and encourages excellence in the field of Biomedical Engineering and Bioengineering. AHMB's "Mentoring for INnovative Design Solutions" (MINDS) Scholar Program provides biomedical engineering students with the opportunity to collaborate and network with peers and mentors across the country for a 5-month period, while building necessary engineering design skills not sufficiently emphasized in regular coursework. For instance, (1) market considerations for commercialization (why is this product needed, what market is there for it and the size of the market), (2) regulatory strategy (what regulations does the product need to meet, and what would be a successful strategy to get the product approved), and (3) evaluating prospects for intellectual property protection (how can the design team protect others from using their idea or copying their product). 

Biomedical engineers must have the knowledge and skills to navigate every step and aspect of bringing a product to market in order to address public healthcare needs. During the program, MINDS Scholars enhance their knowledge of product design, but they also learn how to effectively communicate with collaborators from other schools and organizations using online tools, which are becoming a critical skill in today's work environment. 

Participation in the MINDS Scholar Program is through a competitive application process among biomedical engineering majors. Each annual MINDS Scholar Program starts with a joint workshop, where students meet their team members and mentors, and create an action plan. They select a central design idea that is refined during the 5-month period, and they actively collaborate to advance the project forward, culminating in a final report. 

22 students completed the 2019-2020 program with guidance from 13 mentors. By the end of the program, participants were able to create a novel product idea, describe how they used the key design considerations in the design process, and state the features, benefits and impacts of their products through production of a promotional presentation. Product ideas varied widely, including: Microfluidic Test for Drug Allergy Diagnostics, Microfluidic Arterial Blood Gas Test for Diagnosis of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), Tele-Rehab Mobile Application, Health Tracking Application with Smart Glucose Monitor, Stay Afoot Virtual Reality System for Fall Prevention, Biocompatible Electrode and Lead Wires for a Deep Brain Stimulation Device, and Metal Mesh Delivery Funnel for Breast Implant Surgery.

Students were surveyed at the beginning and end of the program. A majority of students agreed or highly agreed that the MINDS program had improved their perceived skills in understanding the design considerations addressed in the program and applying them to any project, assessing product requirements, explaining key features of a product, communicating technical matters to others,  understanding the product development cycle, collaborating remotely, and working in a team. 70% of the students also reported that MINDS impacted their career goals. The results of the 2019-2020 program, and mentor and student feedback, will be used to improve the program for future cohorts. 

Some quotes from 2019-2020 students were as follows:

"MINDS has encouraged me to consider future options in product design and development, as well as inspired me to consider starting small companies surrounding my project ideas following graduation.  I am definitely more prepared to work in industry after I graduate."

"MINDS has helped expand and develop my existing knowledge of the design and development process.  Working on a project with people from different universities has helped me develop my communication skills to allow me to explain ideas more clearly and concisely"

"The MINDS workshop has taught me that one must take the three design considerations into account when designing a product. A majority of my engineering classes have focused more on the technical aspects of designing a product and have not taken these considerations into account. However, I now realize that these aspects are incredibly important when attempting to develop a new product."

"The MINDS program helped me gain valuable professional skills to help me in my future engineering career. While most of my academic classes have been focused on scientific content, this MINDS opportunity exposed me to the important considerations that go into engineering projects beyond the technical work. Design is so much more than simply creating a device-- design is composed of a complex web of market, regulatory, and intellectual property factors that come into play. I now have direct experience in seeing a design project through from the initial idea stages to a detailed, realistic plan of execution. These skills that I have learned are very valuable for me as I graduate and look to join the engineering community."

In summary, we achieved our aims of teaching students how to integrate market needs, regulatory considerations, and intellectual property strategy into the design process. In doing this, we also increased their awareness of how biomedical devices and technologies can benefit society.
